#Text=[0002] The detection of particular DNA sequences in biological samples plays a decisive role in the area of molecular biology.
#Text=For example, in human and veterinary medical practice numerous infections are diagnosed by the detection of pathogen-specific DNA sequences.
#Text=Furthermore, methods for detecting particular DNA sequences are also used in the identification of genetic variants of particular human genes.
#Text=These genetic variants can be used as markers for the course of the disease and for the therapeutic response in a number of diseases, e.g. in psychiatric and neurological diseases.

#Text=[0003] Usually, for detecting DNA sequences in pathogen diagnostics, amplification techniques are used, for example PCR or RT-PCR, in order to increase the quantity of pathogen-specific DNA contained in the sample.
#Text=In a first step, usually a DNA purification is carried out starting from the respective patient sample (for example blood, serum, tissue, or the like).

#Text=Depending on the nature of pathogen to be detected, the purified DNA can be obtained from bacterial cells or from cells of the affected tissue of the patient in question (e.g. in the case of infection with viruses whose DNA integrates into the genomic DNA of the infected host cells).
#Text=The purified DNA can then be used in the respective amplification method, using primers that are specific with respect to their sequence to the pathogen to be detected.

#Text=[0004] Another possibility for the detection of pathogen-specific DNA sequences is offered by DNA hybridization methods, in which the presence of a defined DNA sequence is detected by hybridization with labeled probes.
#Text=A classical way of carrying out DNA hybridization methods is Southern blotting.

#Text=In this method the DNA isolated from the cells or tissues is, after fragmentation with restriction endonucleases, separated by gel electrophoresis, transferred to a membrane (e.g. a nitro-cellulose or nylon membrane), immobilized and hybridized to an appropriately labeled oligonucleotide probe.
#Text=As an alter-native, the isolated DNA can be put on a membrane directly and then hybridized (dot blot).
#Text=Southern blotting is often employed for investigating gene rearrangements.
#Text=[0005] In addition to Southern blotting, in situ hybridization has also become established in pathogen diagnostics.
#Text=In situ hybridization means the direct detection of nucleic acid sequences in sections and cell preparations using suitable probes.
#Text=This method is already used in many laboratories for detecting viral DNA (cytomegalovirus, herpesviruses, etc.) in tissue sections and in cells.
#Text=In addition, the method can be used for the analysis of structural chromosomal changes.

#Text=[0006] The probes used in DNA hybridization methods can be labeled in various ways, for example with fluorescent molecules or with groups that can be detected immunologically from reaction with an antibody.
#Text=Hybridization methods normally also require purification of the DNA to be investigated.
